title: How to Ride Without Depending on the Horn or the Pommel for Balance

steps.headline: Find out what you are holding onto and why.
steps.description: Are you holding onto the pommel to stop your self from bouncing, or the horn to keep you from falling off?

steps.headline: Learn that when you feel insecure, hold the cloth a little more until you feel confident.

steps.headline: Try holding the cloth with only your little finger, this allows better control and allows you to simply release your little finger without thinking and grabbing hold again.

text: Find out what you are holding onto and why. Are you holding onto the pommel to stop your self from bouncing, or the horn to keep you from falling off? Explain to your riding instructor why you feel insecure and why you prefer to hold the pommel or the horn. They can help you conquer your fears, If you're holding onto the pommel of an English saddle, the process to let go is a little easier. First hold the saddle cloth rather than the saddle, this puts your whole body into a better position, you hand will be at a level that allows for better control. Learn that when you feel insecure, hold the cloth a little more until you feel confident. Each few days, gradually try to loosen your grip and have less fingers holding the cloth. Try holding the cloth with only your little finger, this allows better control and allows you to simply release your little finger without thinking and grabbing hold again. Once you have let go completely, you can ride without a hand support. If you feel insecure, hold onto the mane this way you can still have maximum control, If holding on to the horn of a saddle (Western saddle) it takes a little more effort from the rider. Make sure you have already done steps 1 and 2 at the top of this page. Understand that when  riding in a competition, you will need to understand that you will be disqualified for touching your saddle, so this will encourage you to let go. But if your simply riding a western horse for pleasure, it will take a little more. To begin with, try to ride one handed, you may find that it is a little difficult if you're a novice or a beginner. If it is harder, try two hands at a walk. This will be easier to steer and stop. Ride by trotting and  you will want to grab hold of the saddle again. Try to refrain from doing so and instead sing a song. Think about what you want to do and how your going to do it. Look straight through the horses ears and breath 5 big breaths in and out.# After the 5th breath, stop and adjust yourself. Then do it again, this time take in 7 really big breaths hold for 2 seconds and breath out, repeat 7 times. After a while you will become more relaxed and be thinking of your breathing rather than holding on. Know that at canter or lope, you will want to hold on to the horn or pommel again, repeat the breathing exercises and gradually take your hand from the saddle to the mane. And then finally from the mane to simply holding the reins.
